sen.j: 羽根突き（はねつき）は、1300年の歴史を持つ、日本の正月によく行われる伝統的な遊戯のひとつであり、2人がムクロジの種子に羽を付けたものを羽子板で打ち合う、女子の遊戯や縁起行為である。
sen.e: Hanetsuki with a history of 1,300 years is one of traditional games often played in New Year's Holidays in Japan, and is a girls' game or action for good luck that two players bandy a fletched soapberry seed with Hagoita (battledore).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Hanetsuki, with a history of 1,300 years, is one of traditional games often played in New Year's Holidays in Japan, and is a girls' game or action for good luck where two players bandy a fletched soapberry seed with Hagoita (battledore).

Hanetsuki, with a history of 1,300 years, is one of traditional games often played in New Year's Holidays in Japan, and is a girls' game or action for good luck where two players bandy a fletched soapberry seed with Hagoita (battledore).

sen.j: 元は神事とされる。
sen.e: It used to be a Shinto ritual.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It used to be a Shinto ritual.
It used to be a Shinto ritual.

sen.j: 本来の意味
sen.e: Original meaning
Original meaning
Original meaning

sen.j: 女児が健やかに育つようにという願いを込めて行われる神事であり、古くは奈良時代から続く、公家の間で行われた神事や遊戯であった。
sen.e: Hanetsuki was a Shinto ritual performed in the hope of girls' healthy growth, and was a Shinto ritual or game which had been played among court nobles since the Nara period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Hanetsuki was a Shinto ritual performed in the hope of girls' healthy growth, and was a Shinto ritual or game which had been played among court nobles since the Nara period.
Hanetsuki was a Shinto ritual performed in the hope of girls' healthy growth, and was a Shinto ritual or game which had been played among court nobles since the Nara period.

sen.j: 元は毬杖（ぎちょう）と言った。
sen.e: It was originally called Gi-Cho.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It was originally called Gi-Cho.
It was originally called Gi-Cho.

sen.j: （ちなみに男子には破魔矢・破魔弓が送られ神事としては様々な弓矢がそれにあたる。）
sen.e: (For information, Hamaya (ritual arrows to drive away devils) and Hamayumi (ritual bow used to drive off devils) are given to boys, and as a Shinto ritual, various kinds of bows and arrows are equivalent to those.)

(For information, Hamaya (ritual arrows to drive away devils) and Hamayumi (ritual bow used to drive off devils) are given to boys, and as a Shinto ritual, various kinds of bows and arrows are equivalent to those.)

(For information, Hamaya (ritual arrows to drive away devils) and Hamayumi (ritual bow used to drive off devils) are given to boys, and as a Shinto ritual, various kinds of bows and arrows are equivalent to those.)

sen.j: また羽子板を飾る時期が、主に正月から小正月の1月15日まで飾られることから、この時季に行われることが多い。
sen.e: Since Hagoita is decorated mainly during a period from New Year's Holidays to January 15 of small New Year's festival around January 15, Hanetsuki is often played around this time.
sen.cmt: 「また羽子板を飾る時期が、」の前の”）”は、前文に続くので、前文に付けました。
sen.e: Since Hagoita is decorated mainly during the period from New Year's Holidays to the New Year's festival around January 15, Hanetsuki is often played around this time.
Since Hagoita is decorated mainly during the period from New Year's Holidays to the New Year's festival around January 15, Hanetsuki is often played around this time.

sen.j: 遊び方
sen.e: How to play
How to play
How to play

sen.j: 基本的には1対1の2名で行われる。
sen.e: Basically, Hanetsuki is played by two players on a one-on-one basis.
Basically, Hanetsuki is played by two players on a one-on-one basis.
Basically, Hanetsuki is played by two players on a one-on-one basis.

sen.j: 2人のプレーヤーは向かい合って位置し、それぞれ羽子板（はごいた）とよばれる木製のラケットを持ち、羽根（はね。木製の小球で、もともとはムクロジの種子）に数枚の鳥の羽をさしこんだもの。羽子（はご）ともいう）を打ち合う。
sen.e: Two players who stand opposite each other hold a wooden racket called Hagoita, respectively, and bandy Hane (shuttlecock) (a small wooden ball into which several feathers are put, and a soapberry seed was originally used for the small wooden ball; also called Hago).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処[後列の文章を含めて、一つの文章となっているため、この列にまとめました。]
sen.e: Two players who stand opposite each other hold a wooden racket called Hagoita, respectively, and bandy Hane (shuttlecock) (a small wooden ball into which several feathers are put, and a soapberry seed was originally used for the small wooden ball; also called Hago).

Two players who stand opposite each other hold a wooden racket called Hagoita, respectively, and bandy Hane (shuttlecock) (a small wooden ball into which several feathers are put, and a soapberry seed was originally used for the small wooden ball; also called Hago).

sen.j: ネットや定まった大きさのコートなどはないが、打ちそこなった場合は失点とされ、顔に墨でバツ印などの落書きをされる罰が与えられる。
sen.e: Although nets are not used, and a size of court is not prescribed, a failure to hit Hane is regarded to be a loss, and a failing player receives a penalty of putting a X mark on the face with India ink.

Although nets are not used, and the size of the court is not prescribed, a failure to hit Hane is regarded as a loss, and a failing player receives a penalty of putting an X mark on the face with India ink.

Although nets are not used, and the size of the court is not prescribed, a failure to hit Hane is regarded as a loss, and a failing player receives a penalty of putting an X mark on the face with India ink.

sen.j: 墨を塗る行為も元は縁起行為であり、墨には厄除けや殺菌効果としての病気除けの効果があると考えられていた。
sen.e: The action of painting a face with India ink also used to be an action for good luck, and India ink was considered to have an effect of protection from evil, and of protection from disease due to its antiseptic effect.

The action of painting a face with India ink also used to be an action for good luck, and India ink was considered to have an effect of protection from evil, and of protection from disease due to its antiseptic effect.

The action of painting a face with India ink also used to be an action for good luck, and India ink was considered to have an effect of protection from evil, and of protection from disease due to its antiseptic effect.

sen.j: 現在の社会的認知
sen.e: Current social recognition
Current social recognition
Current social recognition

sen.j: 和服姿の女性や子供たちが興じる姿は、正月の風物詩として報道される。
sen.e: Pictures that ladies and children wearing traditional Japanese clothes enjoy playing Hanetsuki are often reported as seasonal tradition in New Year's Holidays.
Pictures of ladies and children wearing traditional Japanese clothes enjoying playing Hanetsuki are often reported as a seasonal tradition in the New Year's Holidays.
Pictures of ladies and children wearing traditional Japanese clothes enjoying playing Hanetsuki are often reported as a seasonal tradition in the New Year's Holidays.

sen.j: バドミントンに似る。
sen.e: Hanetsuki is similar to badminton.
Hanetsuki is similar to badminton.
Hanetsuki is similar to badminton.

sen.j: またこの罰がこっけいであることから、テレビジョン放送のバラエティ番組などで羽根突きをアレンジしたゲームが行われ、敗者の顔に墨を塗る罰ゲームが行われることも多い。
sen.e: Since the above penalty is funny, games resulting from making a modification to Hanetsuki are played in TV variety programs, and games giving a loser a penalty of painting the face with India ink are often played.

Since the above penalty is funny, games resulting from making a modification to Hanetsuki are played in TV variety programs, and games giving a loser a penalty of painting the face with India ink are often played.

Since the above penalty is funny, games resulting from making a modification to Hanetsuki are played in TV variety programs, and games giving a loser a penalty of painting the face with India ink are often played.

sen.j: 毬杖が時代とともに変化し、杖が羽子板に変化し、毬が羽に変わったと言われる。
sen.e: It is said that Gi-Cho changed with times, and Cho (stick) was replaced by Hagoita, and Gi (ball) was replaced by Hane.
It is said that Gi-Cho changed with times, and Cho (stick) was replaced by Hagoita, and Gi (ball) was replaced by Hane.
It is said that Gi-Cho changed with times, and Cho (stick) was replaced by Hagoita, and Gi (ball) was replaced by Hane.

sen.j: 一説には毬が羽に変化したのは、紐や羽のついた分銅を蹴る武術や舞や遊びが中国から伝わり、日本の毬杖と渾然一体となり現在の羽根突きになったとも言われる。
sen.e: One theory says that the reason why Gi was replaced by Hane was that the martial art, dance or game of kicking a laced or fletched weight was imported from China, and was blended together with Gi-Cho in Japan, and then present-day Hanetsuki was formed.

One theory says that the reason why Gi was replaced by Hane was that the martial art, dance or game of kicking a laced or fletched weight was imported from China, and was blended together with Gi-Cho in Japan, and then present-day Hanetsuki was formed.

One theory says that the reason why Gi was replaced by Hane was that the martial art, dance or game of kicking a laced or fletched weight was imported from China, and was blended together with Gi-Cho in Japan, and then present-day Hanetsuki was formed.

sen.j: （羽子板は日本独自のものである）
sen.e: (Hagoita is specific to Japan.)
(Hagoita is specific to Japan.)
(Hagoita is specific to Japan.)

sen.j: 奈良時代に、男子の神事として蹴鞠（けまり）が存在したのに対し、女子には毬杖が行われていた。
sen.e: In the Nara period, Kemari (ancient football game in Japan) existed as a Shinto ritual for boys, while Gi-Cho was performed for girls.
In the Nara period, Kemari (ancient football game in Japan) existed as a Shinto ritual for boys, while Gi-Cho was performed for girls.
In the Nara period, Kemari (ancient football game in Japan) existed as a Shinto ritual for boys, while Gi-Cho was performed for girls.

sen.j: （毬杖とは、箆のような杖で毬を打ち合う遊びであり、神事であった。）
sen.e: (Gi-Cho was a game of bandying Gi (ball) with Cho (stick) shaped like Noh (spatula), and was a Shinto ritual.)
(Gi-Cho was a game of bandying Gi (ball) with Cho (stick) shaped like Noh (spatula), and was a Shinto ritual.)
(Gi-Cho was a game of bandying Gi (ball) with Cho (stick) shaped like Noh (spatula), and was a Shinto ritual.)

sen.j: 室町時代には、杖（「毬杖」というが、毬杖の神事と紛らわしいので「杖」とする）は羽子板に変化し、毬は無患子（むくろじ）の木の実に羽をつけた物に変化した。
sen.e: In the Muromachi period, a stick (although it was called 'Gi-Cho,' the term 'stick' is used here in order to avoid confusion with Gi-Cho as a Shinto ritual) was transformed into Hagoita, and a ball was transformed into a fletched soapberry nut.

In the Muromachi period, a stick (although it was called 'Gi-Cho,' the term 'stick' is used here in order to avoid confusion with Gi-Cho as a Shinto ritual) was transformed into Hagoita, and a ball was transformed into a fletched soapberry nut.

In the Muromachi period, a stick (although it was called 'Gi-Cho,' the term 'stick' is used here in order to avoid confusion with Gi-Cho as a Shinto ritual) was transformed into Hagoita, and a ball was transformed into a fletched soapberry nut.

sen.j: 現在の羽根突きとほとんど変わらぬ様式となり、公家の間で「こぎの子勝負」といった羽根突き大会が行わた。
sen.e: Gi-Cho changed to the form almost similar to present-day Hanetsuki, and Hanetsuki taikai (Japanese badminton tournament) called 'Koginoko shobu' was held among court nobles.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Gi-Cho changed to the form almost similar to present-day Hanetsuki, and Hanetsuki taikai (Japanese badminton tournament) called 'Koginoko shobu' was held among court nobles.
Gi-Cho changed to the form almost similar to present-day Hanetsuki, and Hanetsuki taikai (Japanese badminton tournament) called 'Koginoko shobu' was held among court nobles.

sen.j: これは、男女対抗戦であり、負けた方が、酒を振舞ったとされる。
sen.e: This was a competition between men and women, and it is said that losers entertained winners with sake.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This was a competition between men and women, and it is said that losers entertained winners with sake.
This was a competition between men and women, and it is said that losers entertained winners with sake.

sen.j: この無患子は「子が患（わずら）わ無い」と表記するので女児への無病息災の願いが込められている。
sen.e: As the term "soapberry" use Japanese characters meaning 'children without disease,' a wish for perfect state of health of girls was contained.
As the term "soapberry" uses Japanese characters meaning 'children without disease,' a wish for a perfect state of health of girls was contained.
As the term "soapberry" uses Japanese characters meaning 'children without disease,' a wish for a perfect state of health of girls was contained.

sen.j: 戦国時代には祭礼の要素が強くなり、羽根突きよりも羽子板に祓いや縁起としての装飾が施され、縁起物の装飾品としての色合いを帯びていった。
sen.e: In the Sengoku period (period of warring state), since a factor of rites and festivals became stronger, decorations as exorcism or luck were provided to Hagoita rather than Hanetsuki, and Hagoita came to be tinged with an accessory as lucky charm.

In the Sengoku period (period of warring states), since the factor of rites and festivals became stronger, decorations as exorcism or luck were provided to Hagoita rather than Hanetsuki, and Hagoita came to be tinged with an accessory as a lucky charm.

In the Sengoku period (period of warring states), since the factor of rites and festivals became stronger, decorations as exorcism or luck were provided to Hagoita rather than Hanetsuki, and Hagoita came to be tinged with an accessory as a lucky charm.

sen.j: この頃には羽根を蜻蛉に見立て、蚊に刺されないようにとの願いが込められていたことが文献に記述されている。
sen.e: A literature said that around this time, Hane was regarded as a dragonfly, and a wish for protecting from mosquito bites was contained.
Literature from around this time said that Hane was regarded as a dragonfly, and a wish for protecting from mosquito bites was contained.
Literature from around this time said that Hane was regarded as a dragonfly, and a wish for protecting from mosquito bites was contained.

sen.j: 当時の疫病は蚊を媒介として広まることが多く蚊除けは大事な事であった。
sen.e: As infectious diseases often spread by the medium of mosquitoes, the protection from mosquitoes was important at that time.
As infectious diseases often spread by the medium of mosquitoes, the protection from mosquitoes was important at that time.
As infectious diseases often spread by the medium of mosquitoes, the protection from mosquitoes was important at that time.

sen.j: 江戸時代には、武家が女児の誕生を祝って羽子板を贈答するようになった。
sen.e: In the Edo period, samurai families started presenting Hagoita in celebration of girl's birth.
In the Edo period, samurai families started presenting Hagoita in celebration of girl's birth.
In the Edo period, samurai families started presenting Hagoita in celebration of girl's birth.

sen.j: またこれが庶民にも伝わり、女児のいる家庭に縁起物の歳暮として年の暮れに贈られるようになった。
sen.e: This custom spread among the common people, and it became popular to present Hagoita to families with girls as seibo (year-end gift) of lucky charm at the end of the year.
This custom spread among the common people, and it became popular to present Hagoita to families with girls as seibo (year-end gift) of lucky charms at the end of the year.
This custom spread among the common people, and it became popular to present Hagoita to families with girls as seibo (year-end gift) of lucky charms at the end of the year.

sen.j: このことが正月に羽根突きが行われることの由来となっている。
sen.e: This was the origin of playing Hanetsuki in New Year's Holidays.
This was the origin of playing Hanetsuki in New Year's Holidays.
This was the origin of playing Hanetsuki in New Year's Holidays.

sen.j: コギノキという木は、その種子が羽根突きの羽に形が似ていることから、「突く羽・衝羽根（ツクバネ）」と名づけられた。
sen.e: Since a tree called Koginoki whose seed looks like Hane of Hanetsuki, it was named 'Tsukubane' after 'tsuku Hane' (striking a shuttlecock).
Since a tree exists called Koginoki, whose seed looks like the Hane of Hanetsuki, it was named 'Tsukubane' after 'tsuku Hane' (striking a shuttlecock).
Since a tree exists called Koginoki, whose seed looks like the Hane of Hanetsuki, it was named 'Tsukubane' after 'tsuku Hane' (striking a shuttlecock).

sen.j: 羽子板には装飾用に作られるものもあり、人物像や花鳥の図が布の押し絵で豪華に作りつけられる（詳細は羽子板の項を参照のこと）。
sen.e: Hagoita is sometimes made for decoration, and is decorated luxuriously with raised cloth pictures of portraits, and designs of flowers and birds (for details, refer to the article of Hagoita).
Hagoita is sometimes made for decoration, and is decorated luxuriously with raised cloth pictures of portraits, and designs of flowers and birds (for details, refer to the article of Hagoita).
Hagoita is sometimes made for decoration, and is decorated luxuriously with raised cloth pictures of portraits, and designs of flowers and birds (for details, refer to the article of Hagoita).

tit.e: Haneuta (A song that goes with Hanetsuki)
Haneuta (A song that goes with Hanetsuki)
Haneuta (A song that goes with Hanetsuki)

sen.j: 羽子歌（はねうた）は、羽根突きにうたう歌である。
sen.e: Haneuta is a song sung when playing Hanetsuki.
Haneuta is a song sung when playing Hanetsuki.
Haneuta is a song sung when playing Hanetsuki.

sen.j: 歌詞の一例は、「一（ひと）ごに二（ふた）ご、三（み）わたし四（よ）めご、五（い）つ来ても六（む）かし、七（なな）んの八（や）くし、九（ここ）のまへで十（とを）よ」。
sen.e: One example of the words is 'Hito (one) go ni Futa (two) go, Mi (three) watashi Yo (four) mego, I (five) tsu kitemo, Mu (six) kashi, Nana (seven) n no Ya (eight) kushi, Koko (nine) no maede To (ten) yo.'
sen.cmt: 意味が不明でしたので、歌詞は、その読みのまま表記し、読みが括弧で記載された数字の部分のみ(one), (two) 等と表記しました。
sen.e: One example of the words is 'Hito (one) go ni Futa (two) go, Mi (three) watashi Yo (four) mego, I (five) tsu kitemo, Mu (six) kashi, Nana (seven) n no Ya (eight) kushi, Koko (nine) no maede To (ten) yo.'

One example of the words is 'Hito (one) go ni Futa (two) go, Mi (three) watashi Yo (four) mego, Itsu (five) kitemo, Mu (six) kashi, Nana (seven) n no Ya (eight) kushi, Koko (nine) no maede To (ten) yo.'
sen.cmt: 括弧の位置を訂正しました。

sen.j: また、「一ごに二ご、三わたし四めご、五つ来て見ても、七（なな）子（こ）の帯を、八（や）の字にしめて、九（ここ）のはで十（と）かした」。
sen.e: Or, 'Hito go ni Futa go, Mi watashi Yomego, Itsu kitemitemo, Nana (seven) ko no obi wo, Ya (eight) noji ni shimete, Koko (nine) nohade To (ten) kashita.'
sen.cmt: 意味が不明でしたので、歌詞は、その読みのまま表記し、読みが括弧で記載された数字の部分のみ(one), (two) 等と表記しました。
sen.e: Or, 'Hito go ni Futa go, Mi watashi Yomego, Itsu kitemitemo, Nana (seven) ko no obi wo, Ya (eight) noji ni shimete, Koko (nine) nohade To (ten) kashita.'
Or, 'Hito go ni Futa go, Mi watashi Yomego, Itsu kitemitemo, Nana (seven) ko no obi wo, Ya (eight) noji ni shimete, Koko (nine) nohade To (ten) kashita.'

sen.j: また、「一人（ひとり）来（き）な二人（ふたり）来な、三人（さんにん）来たら、四（よ）つて来な、五（い）つ来て見ても、七子（ななこ）の帯を、八（や）たらにしめて、九（ここ）のまへで十（とを）よ」。
sen.e: Or 'Hitori (one person) kina, Futari (two persons) kina, Sannin (three persons) kitara, Yo (four) ttekina, I (five) tsukite mitemo, Nana (seven) ko no obiwo, Ya (eight) tara ni shimete, Koko (nine) no maede To (ten) yo.'
sen.cmt: 意味が不明でしたので、歌詞は、その読みのまま表記し、読みが括弧で記載された数字の部分のみ(one person), (two persons), (four) 等と表記しました。
sen.e: Or 'Hitori (one person) kina, Futari (two persons) kina, Sannin (three persons) kitara, Yo (four) ttekina, I (five) tsukite mitemo, Nana (seven) ko no obiwo, Ya (eight) tara ni shimete, Koko (nine) no maede To (ten) yo.'
Or 'Hitori (one) kina, Futari (two) kina, Sannin (three) kitara, Yotte (four) kina, Itsu (five) kite mitemo, Nana (seven) ko no obiwo, Ya (eight) tara ni shimete, Koko (nine) no maede To (ten) yo.'
sen.cmt: (one), (two) 等の表記に訂正しました。音節の区切りに括弧の位置を訂正しました。
